article:
'List of Masonic buildings in the United States' identifies the notable
buildings in the United States that were constructed by Masonic bodies for
Masonic purposes or that have some other strong association with Freemasonry.
Often these buildings are formally named or popularly referred to as "Masonic
Halls", "Masonic Centers", or "Masonic Temples". Another common term for such
buildings is "Masonic Lodge", although some, including Masonic writers and
teachers, reserve use of this term to refer to the
organizational bodies that meet within the buildings, and not to the buildings
themselves.

Many buildings that were built to house Masonic lodge meetings and ritual
activities are now regarded as landmarks. In other cases, Masonic bodies
converted existing landmark buildings to Masonic use. William
D. Moore (2006), [http://books.google.com/books?id=TAEZopwOKNYC Masonic temples:
Freemasonry, Ritual Architecture, and Masculine Archetypes], University of
Tennessee Press. ISBN 1-57233-496-7, ISBN 978-1-57233-496-0. Many
buildings of both types are now listed on heritage registers.

In the United States, the decades between 1870 and 1930 were a prolific period
of construction by Masonic bodies. Several prominent American architects
designed buildings for Masonic bodies during this period, including Burnham and
Root, John Russell Pope and John C. Austin.

Although the Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine (commonly
known as the Shriners) is not part of Freemasonry as such, [http://www.ben-ali-
shriners.org/Masonicfaq.htm Masonic FAQs], Ben Ali Shrine Center (Sacramento,
California) website, accessed August 30, 2010. FAQ #4 states: "The Shrine is not
an appendant body of Masonry, though the distinction would escape many."
some buildings constructed or used by that group are included on this list.
Membership in Freemasonry is a prerequisite for joining the
Shrine, [http://www.shrinershq.org/ShrinersHQ/Membership/ Frequently Asked
Questions], Shriners International website, accessed August 30, 2010 local
bodies of the two groups sometimes meet in the same buildings, and the Shrine
Order sometimes is popularly assumed to be part of Freemasonry.

Notable buildings built by Masonic bodies, or extensively used for Masonic
purposes, are grouped by state.
categories: Masonic buildings in the United States|
